reviewText: Wisdom learned the hard way: never try to watch Ellen when it hurts to laugh.It's 2003, and she looks so young, so sweet, so innocent. And of course she knows how to use that face for laughs. She starts with the obligatory gay jokes, just to get it over with, and gets in a few zingers like the people who worry that others will think they are gay because they showed up at this show. But once she's had some five to ten minutes of getting that subject out of the way, the rest is her stream-of-consciousness that, for example, dissects procrastination and turns it to a thing to be proud of. She makes the point that people are forever worrying what other people are thinking of them, when in fact what they are thinking is worrying what you think of them. A variety of minor embarrassing moments are flawlessly executed.Ellen has the gift of being able to say what the rest of us only think. Yoga, for example. It's really about paying for quiet. So you get yourself in a lotus position, get all your chakras properly aligned, looking out at the world with your third eye, and trying to appreciate the silence. What do you hear? An advertising jingle!

reviewText: I laughed so hard the first time I watched "Ellen DeGeneres - Here and Now," I actually had tears rolling down my face (a rarity for me).  Even though I've watched it several times now, it still makes me laugh.  I can relate to so many things:  procrastinating (with unfinished jobs all over the house); forgetting what I was going to say; waving at the wrong person; tripping then pretending to jog; singing the wrong words to songs; etc.  On top of that, Ellen's humor is quite "clean" compared to most routines heard these days.  I highly recommend this DVD for anyone looking for some good, clean laughs.

reviewText: In 2003, Ellen DeGeneres embarked on a 35-date tour with her stand-up comedy.  In the meantime, she sold out several dates.  Through it all, she received rave reviews from many critics, describing it as hilarious and entertaining.  "Here And Now" explores her New York visit, which is no exception.  Her routine expresses how great of a comedienne she truly is.  This DVD is one of three performances that proves that 2003 was her biggest year since 1997, the year she came out with her sexuality.  The premiere of her new show "The Ellen Show" and receiving rave reviews for her performance on "Finding Nemo" followed.Though nothing beats the live experience, "Here And Now" commemorates that beautifully.  It explores a variety of topics, including procrastination, technology, music, and others.  Though many may expect gay issues, she shares them briefly.  She proves herself as one of the most unique comediennes of modern day.  Amazingly, she can act out the simplest things, and audiences react with hardcore laughs.  Even pushing a button and eating popcorn become unforgettable scenes.  Unlike many other bigname comedians/ comediennes, her performances are mostly vocal rather than physical.  Such talents prove that her humor is natural.  Her expressions through her voice and her face wonderfully add to the fun.  Nothing controversial is featured in this performance (not that controversy is a bad thing).  She never uses any discriminatory words.  Through the laughter, she acknowledges the true importances in life.Her great performance makes "Here And Now" worth watching several times.  This is sure to keep audiences laughing through the entire hour feature.  Such talents prove that Ellen DeGeneres will continue releasing great performances for many more years.

reviewText: I had a friend get this dvd for my girlfriend after watching it on HBO.  Gotta LOVE Ellen.  She manages to do an entire stand-up comedy routine with endless laughter and tact.She starts with the whole gay thing and within a couple of minutes lets it go.  Her comedy is clean, funny, quick-witted and genious!  This dvd is 100% appropriate for all walks of life and Ellen doesn't miss a beat.I kind of liked Ellen before but after watching her on HBO (this dvd) and her show "Ellen", she is absolutely the most talented comedian we have in American society today!This was Chris Rock's year to host the Oscars but after seeing this and getting to know Ellen a little better, I cannot imagine a more sophisticated and down-to-earth host for the Academy Awards! I would love to see her be the new host.If you haven't had the pleasure of reviewing this dvd, do so immediately, you will laugh so hard and just feel better about life!  Thank you, Ellen!
summary: If Ellen is The Best Rate me a "Yes"

reviewText: I really enjoyedEllen Degeneres - The Beginning (Keepcase), but this one was even better. Ellen Morgan on the show Ellen makes me laugh like crazy, but Ellen as herself is even funnier.I especially have to give Ellen credit for the quality of this DVD. Not one curse word that I noticed, no gross sex jokes. ("The Beginning" had just a few but was still pretty PG.) So many comedians - and TV shows and movies, but mostly comedians - these days cannot get a laugh without being dirty. You know you have immense talent when the audience is rolling on the floor when you are talking about light bulbs, or rolling down car windows.My favorite part was Ellen's irritation with cell phones. I have the same frustration with them myself, and I couldn't have said it more perfectly!

reviewText: This is a really good DVD of a HBO special that Ellen DeGeneres taped last year. I really enjoy her sense of humor, and she packs a great punch with it. I find her humor to be more subtle, she just sort of lays it out there with her comments about every day life, and things we can identify with. There were a lot of good jokes, like the ones about those motion sensor toilets and sinks, there was a great joke about "go-gurt" and just everyday things. I really enjoyed the DVD, she is not explicit. Her delivery is great, she is trying to be funny and make jokes obviously but she does it so effortlessly you don't even realize she's doing it, it just comes out of her mouth like anything else. Really good DVD, you'll love it if you're a big Ellen fan, and if you're not then you should check this out and I'm sure you'll find something you'll love about it!

reviewText: Ellen is the "Dalai Lama" of our era's sociological crisis, understanding the fundamental issue that has critically impacted human nature as a whole, and on an individual level.  "Here and Now" is a masterful presentation that brings to our attention the heart of American life today.  It's amazing how eloquently she nail's the vague, deeply unsettling core adversity that represents the hallmark of American citizens lives today, while making us laugh hysterically at our weakness.I've always admired Ellen, seeing in her a wise, compassionate, deep soul that loves and understands people.  She has courageously sacrificed herself to offer humanity a kind service with the gift of her humor, even as she vulnerably exposed her true self publicly, knowing she would face the heavy burden of society's judgement.  In "Here and Now", Ellen has never been more beautiful, witty, humble and radiant, a woman who has attained her full potential with grace, and this all makes the subject matter of her show more touching on a personal level.This is a must-see for all, especially for baby-boomers and early Gen-Xer's, who will so easily relate and laugh at ourselves and our lives, poignantly bringing us back in touch with life before the chaos, when things were so much simpler, and joy could be experienced in the little things that mattered.Bravo, Ellen!  What a beautiful way to share your vision and help us all more aware that we can make life what we want it to be more like - if we choose.  I could not help but enjoy the show even more so, for "seeing" that lovable little blue fish called Dori in my mind - they both share so much in common.
summary: Ellen shines in this briliant, witty, poignant look at life today, and how much has changed!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This comedy special, which originally aired on HBO, was the first sign that Ellen had the goods to be a great talk-show host. Her energy level--she dances to and sings "Shoop" at the end of her set--is matched by the hilarity of her observations about, well, everything. Coiling phone cords of bygone days, organizational schemes for CD collections, the words "just kidding"--nothing escapes her notice, and the laughs and knowing nods keep rolling for an hour. Between this special and her vocal work on "Finding Nemo," it's not hard to tell why Ellen's popularity exploded in 2003 and why her talk show is still going strong today. Your only regret when the show's over will be that she didn't make this DVD longer!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Put aside any notions of Ellen you have from the Ellen Degeneres show. I have watched the show and not found it particularly funny. Here and Now, on the other hand, was extremely funny (if you like the show, this will probably be even better). Ellen pokes fun at everyday occurrences and wraps everything up in a theme which everyone can probably relate to: procrastination. Here and Now offered profound thoughts in ways that don't require too much thought... It was a very well-spent hour.

reviewText: Not only have I seen this HBO Show, I was also in the audience for the taping of this, what can only be described as mesmerising, stand-up performance by Ellen.  I travelled over form Belfast to see the show, got front row seats and was also fortunate enough to get to ask the lady a question at the end of the show.....wot a lady (I am hoping there may be extrs of audience questions....).  This DVD testifies the irrepressible force that is Degeneres, and is a great catch-up opportunity for anyone not familiar with Ellen prior to her daytime talk show (I've seen about 10 shows of it and they're a riot!).  This stand-up show digresses around the theme of procrastination, containing laff-out loud and painfully realistic observations of everyday human idiosyncranices....from the brilliant observation of brand new cds to the riotous observations of waving at someone you think you know, I was rolling in the aisles at this.  My hat goes off to her, she has fought adversity in recent years and come out (metaphorically, lol) a true winner....Finding Nemo, an awesome talk-show and this truly original and entertaining fun show...the lady has it all.  Worth putting in your loved ones' Xmas stocking....laughter the best therapy and Degeneres is the cure.

reviewText: The central theme/topic of the show is procrastination. We get to hear Ellen's very funny anecdotes about it as she opened and ended the show. ("Procrastinate now, don't put it off") She also gets to do jokes based on everyday life observations, from the mundane things possible. From one ply tissue paper to automatic flushing of toilets, to the obligatory gay jokes to packaging of CDs and light bulbs to the shampoo commercial, she just gave amusing observations.I like Ellen's comedy because she doesn't try hard to be funny, she is just effortlessly funny. Unlike other stand up comedians who think profanity automatically means funny, she doesn't need that. She relies on good material that is simply funny. And watch out for her facial expressions as they enhanced her jokes immenselyGrade: A-
summary: Buy this now, don't put it off!!
